stem:
The nurse is assessing a 6-month-old infant with bronchiolitis. Auscultation reveals widespread wheezing and crackles. The infant's respiratory rate is 68 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. The infant is retracting and has nasal flaring. Based on these findings, the nurse should FIRST implement which of the following interventions? Use the drop down menu to answer the question. 

Administer [dropdown] oxygen.

rationale.correct: Providing humidified supplemental oxygen is the priority intervention for an infant with bronchiolitis and low oxygen saturation. Humidified oxygen prevents the infant's airway from drying out, which can worsen respiratory distress. This improves oxygenation and reduces the work of breathing.

mnemonic.name: ABCs
mnemonic.description: Airway, Breathing, Circulation - always prioritize these in that order.

rationale.incorrect:
Delaying humidified oxygen administration could lead to further hypoxia, increased airway irritation, and respiratory failure. While other routes of medication administration or types of oxygen delivery may be necessary later, they are not the priority when the patient is hypoxic and requires airway support.

Oral oxygen is not a route of administration.

Nebulized oxygen is a method of delivering medication, not a type of oxygen.

Intramuscular oxygen is not a route of administration.

questionTrap.whyItIsWrong: While other interventions may be necessary, addressing hypoxia with humidified oxygen is the most immediate need to prevent further respiratory compromise.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Failing to prioritize humidified oxygenation when assessing a patient with respiratory distress, or confusing the route of administration.

clinicalPearls: Bronchiolitis is a common respiratory infection in infants and young children that causes inflammation and obstruction of the small airways.
Oxygen saturation should be maintained above 90% in infants with bronchiolitis.
Early intervention with humidified oxygen can prevent respiratory failure and reduce airway irritation.
Humidified oxygen is preferred in infants to prevent drying of the mucous membranes.

itemContext.sbar:
14:00, Nurse Amy reports:

Situation: 6-month-old infant admitted for bronchiolitis, experiencing increased work of breathing and low oxygen saturation.

Background: Patient presented to the ED with a 3-day history of cough, congestion, and fever. Diagnosed with bronchiolitis based on clinical findings.

Assessment: Respiratory rate 68, oxygen saturation 88% on room air, widespread wheezing and crackles, nasal flaring, and retractions. Alert but irritable.

Recommendation: Requesting orders for humidified oxygen therapy and further evaluation of respiratory status. Consider respiratory therapy consult.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 13:55 Heart Rate: 160 bpm Respiratory Rate: 68 breaths/min Oxygen Saturation: 88% on room air Temperature: 38.5°C (101.3°F) Blood Pressure: 90/60 mmHg

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: 13:30 CBC: WBC: 12,000/mm3 Lymphocytes: 70% Neutrophils: 30% Respiratory Viral Panel: Positive for RSV

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: 13:50 General: Alert, irritable infant in respiratory distress. Respiratory: Nasal flaring, retractions, widespread wheezing and crackles bilaterally. Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, regular rhythm. Neurological: Alert and responsive to stimuli.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: 13:45 Chest X-ray: Hyperinflation Increased peribronchial markings

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Current Plan: Monitor respiratory status continuously. Administer humidified oxygen as needed to maintain oxygen saturation >90%. Suction nasal secretions as needed. Administer antipyretics for fever.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Medications: Acetaminophen 120mg PO q4-6h PRN for fever Normal Saline Nasal Drops PRN for nasal congestion
